Title: plums from the tree

 Written by Raven Ruiz (Raven Cruz-James). Original code created by Adam Smith (amsmith@ucsc.edu) can be found at (https://github.com/rndmcnlly/StoryGraphTool).

Childhood Home.Label: Front porch
Childhood Home.Body: You find yourself in front of your childhood home. It has changed; the siding is a neutral, marketable gray. There's something missing, but you can't quite put your finger on it.

door open.Label: Front porch
door open.Body: An unfamiliar person answers the door. "Can I help you?" they ask.

peek.Label: Front porch
peek.Body: You caution a glance past the stranger's shoulder. The walls behind them are coated in white paint and lined with tasteful, marketable decor. The stranger's smile fades, and they politely ask you to leave.

rejected.Label: Front porch
rejected.Body: The stranger's smile fades for only a moment, but when it returns it's clearly strained. "I don't know who you are," they say. "I think you should leave."

Childhood Home 2.Label: Front porch
Childhood Home 2.Body: You find yourself in front of your childhood home. It has changed; it is no longer your home.

fence now.Label: Side of house, front
fence now.Body: This fence is pine-orange and new with a blank space in the sky -- also new -- over the top of it. There used to be a plum tree. It used to fill that void.

side now.Label: Side of house, back
side now.Body: The side yard feels oddly hollow. There's a perfect patch of grass beneath the pine-new fence instead of a plum tree. The old shed is still there, though, and it's the same gray as the siding.

backyard now.Label: Backyard
backyard now.Body: The dimensions are exactly as you remember them, only now this yard is half-filled with some more perfect grass. On the patio, there's a nice propane grill -- one of those with built-in granite counters. Toward the back fence, there's an in-ground pool.

caught.Label: Backyard
caught.Body: You don't make it two steps before the person who answered the door earlier bursts from the glass door off the patio. "Leave right now," they shout. "Or I'll call the police!"

run 1.Label: Backyard
run 1.Body: Obliging, you hurry back the way you came.

run 2.Label: Side of house
run 2.Body: You slam through the side gate.

home 1.Label: Front porch
home 1.Body: You find yourself in front of your childhood home. It is as it always is; the siding is a warm, faded yellow. There's nothing missing, but you feel oddly hollow all the same.

home.Label: Front porch
home.Body: You find yourself in front of your home. It is as it always is; the siding is a warm, faded yellow. There's nothing missing, but you feel oddly hollow all the same.

knock.Label: Front porch
knock.Body: "It's open!" calls a familiar voice, and of course it is. It always was.

foyer.Label: Foyer
foyer.Body: The walls are covered with patterned wallpaper and lined with photos of your family. To your left, the hall; to your right, the kitchen.

hall.Label: Hall
hall.Body: Yellow light cascades from a bulb in the ceiling. The carpet is brown; the walls are bare except for an heirloom cross and three doors.

past room.Label: Your bedroom
past room.Body: The walls are covered with posters of your favorite band. The bed is unmade, its comforter a tangled mess of colorful polka dots, its pillows askew and mismatched. There's a desk in the corner and a closet door on the opposite side of wall. This is your bedroom.

past desk.Label: Your bedroom
past desk.Body: The wood is reddish brown and study despite its age; your grandma let you have it when you graduated sixth grade. There's a couple of figurines -- characters from that cartoon you watched all the time -- and a pile of books. You used to love reading.

Body.Main: You have to forcefully pry the drawer open because it's absolutely stuffed with old homework, birthday cards, pencils, and the like.
Body.Conditional: In the corner, the bright red of your pocketknife draws your eye.

knife take.Body: You put the knife in your pocket.

past closet.Label: Your bedroom
past closet.Body: The closet is dark and cramped and only as wide as its door. Well-worn band tees and skinny jeans hang heavy enough to bow the rod, and the rest of your clothes are stuffed haphazardly on the top shelf or, to you mother's chagrin, on the floor.

Body.Main: You take a closer look at the baseboard just inside the closet.
Body.Conditional: Your name is carved into the wood.

Body.Main: You take out your pocketknife and carve your name into the wood of the baseboard. You set the knife on the floor.

present closet.Body: Blinking, you suddenly find yourself in a new closet. No, not new -- the same closet, only different. It's tidier and smells vaguely of paint. In the baseboard, stark white gloss has been scratched away to reveal your name, after all these years.

present room.Body: The walls are covered with posters of that one band -- the one you heard on the radio nonstop last summer. The bed is unmade, its comforter a tangled mess of black and white stripes, its pillows askew and mismatched. There's a desk in the corner and a closet door on the opposite side of wall. This is no longer your bedroom.

kitchen.Label: Kitchen
kitchen.Body: A wide window spills its warm sunshine across beige laminate countertops and lacquered wood cabinets. The counters are a mess of mail and car keys and over-ripe fruit. This is the heart of your home, and you are struck with the disconcerting feeling that it always will be, even when home grows legs and runs far away from this place.

countertop.Label: Kitchen
countertop.Body: You mom's key ring has a trinket you made for her in kindergarten, her car key, the house key, and about forty other keys that you have never seen her use. There's an unopened envelop with "FINAL NOTICE" printed across its front; the sender is some mortgage firm you wouldn't have recognized at this age, but you will soon find out just how final that notice is. The sweet smell of summer plums is floating on the air.

pantry.Label: Kitchen
pantry.Body: Cereal boxes, canned beans, a huge bag of rice, assorted snacks.

Body.Main: Inside the drawer lies an apparent disaster zone. You could probably find about anything in here. Old promotional mail coupons, dead batteries, and dozens of rubber bands salvaged from produce or newpapers; years-old stocking-stuffers, loose change, and an eyeglass repair kit from the 99 Cent Store back when everthing was actually 99 cents.
Body.Conditional: On top of it all, a ziploc bag holding a bunch of keys.

key take.Body: You take the keys and tuck them into your pocket. They may come in handy.

past yard.Label: Backyard
past yard.Body: The dimensions are exactly as you remember them, and the yard is filled with patchy grass and dandelions. At the edge of the patio, there's a charcoal kettle grill with rust clinging to its lower hemisphere. Right in the center of everything, there's a 10-foot round, blue doughboy.

Body.Main: A faint smell of burnt hamburger patties past and endless summer fills your senses.
Body.Conditional: Sticking in the dirt just beyond the base of the grill and the patio's edge is a gardening spade.

take spade.Body: You pull the spade from the earth and knock loose clods of dirt off of its curved planes. You tuck it handle-first into your back pocket.

pool.Label: Backyard
pool.Body: The patchy grass fades to mud as you approach the pool. You reach an arm over its edge. The plastic rim has gone hot and pliable under the sun, and the water is lukewarm on the surface but chillier the deeper you plunge your arm.

past fence.Label: Side of house, front
past fence.Body: This fence is dark brown, rained-on, and a little warped with age. There is no void above it; the sky is filled by a plum tree, limbs purpled and bowing under the weight of its fruit.

past side.Label: Side of house, back
past side.Body: The grass is patchy beneath the fence, and tree limbs heavy with ripe plums cast a pleasantly cool and sun-mottled shadow across the whole of the side yard. The old shed is there, of course, and it's the same baby blue you and your mom painted it a few summers back.

plum tree.Label: Side of house, back
plum tree.Body: Store-bought could never compete with the earthy sweetness of your plum tree's fruit. You grew up in this shade, its shape etched permanently into your skin like saccharine respite from years worth of summer sun.

Body.Main: You pluck a plum from heavy-beckoning limbs. Nestled safely out of sight is an old bird's nest sitting in the crook of a darkened knot of fungus. Even now it is eating your tree from within. The plum, nonetheless, is every bit as perfect as you remember.

pocket the seed.Body: You scrape all of that nectar-sweet flesh from the plum's gnarled pit and hold the seed in the hollow of your palm.

side now 2.Label: Side of house, back
side now 2.Body: When you look back up, the side yard feels oddly hollow. There's a perfect patch of grass beneath a pine-new fence instead of the plum tree. The old shed is still there, though, and it's the same gray as the siding.

Body.Main: You kneel to the naked, plumless earth, and you start to dig

plant.Label: Side of house, back
plant.Body: Once you've driven a hole you deem deep enough, you take the plum seed and deliver it to the earth. You push the soil back into place and distantly hope that it will be enough.

endgame warning.Body: Wait. Is there anything else you want to explore before opening this door?

inside shed 1.Body: You swing open the door to reveal -- Huh.

inside shed 2.Body: Not as you are but as you were.

inside shed 3.Body: It's like you opened the door to reveal a mirror through time. You know that's not your face, not anymore, not for many years. Yet there you are, ruddy-cheeked and bruised-knee and new, staring right up at you.

Choices.Text: No, not at you. Past you.

inside shed 4.Body: You follow the reflectionâ€™s gaze -- your own gaze -- to a spot over your shoulder.

inside shed 5.Body: Only with more gray at your temples and deeper lines around your eyes, your lips, your cheeks. It's you as you will be, you think. The three of you stand in the shade of three plum trees.

endgame 1.Body: Through the shed door, that unlikely portal, a version of you whose life was simple and ripe with nectar-sweet happiness that you crave in the ever-increasing heat of your summers. Just over your shoulder, a version of you that you have yet to meet; the lines of their face like messages carved into wood in a language you have yet to learn.

endgame 2.Body: And then there's you, and the choice to be made.

ending: past.Body: Nothing since could ever compete with the earthy sweetness of your own youth. Childhood beckons like limbs heavy with ripe fruit, so you answer its call. You step through the shed door. You go back. You become what you always were, walk effortlessly into a place where most could only ever dream of going. This is a return; this is springtime beneath a plum tree, its blossoms unfurling like magic year after year, all hopeful and new. The sun is warm, and you haven't a care in the world.

ending: present.Body: The shape of your childhood is etched into your skin like saccharine respite from years worth of summer sun, but this future hums in your ear like hope. You shut the shed door and keep your memories where they are, carved infallibly into the nectar-heavy flesh of your heart like a word set in wood. This is a new door; this is the infinite promise of time in its forward march. Endless springs bearing fruit, endless autumns enriching the earth with sweet rot, endless springs bearing fruit. Ahead of you is still you; you will be as you will be. You hold your future in the hollow of your palm like a plum seed, all sticky and new and yours for the planting.
